page.title: 01Weald S of Oakwood Hill
page.content: This is a mixture of farmland and woodland, the only settlements being Wallis Wood and the tiny hamlet of Oakwood Hill with its cricket club and pub widely famed for good food. Outside these the population is virtually limited to the occupants of various farmhouses which are the prominent feature of the landscape. Several of these are very old and very fine, much extended and improved over the years, and suggest an income not confined to farming. The farming is mostly pasture with sheep predominating, but there is also a fair amount of arable. In the woods there are pheasants, some of them reared, and a few wild deer. This is border country, ie the now little used "border path" between Sussex and Surrey runs through east west.
